array.string: I understand the medical terms specific for my health condition/disability.
I can answer questions from my healthcare team about my health condition/disability.
I know the symptoms or complications specific to my health conditions/disability.
I am aware of any allergies I have and how to manage them.
I have discussed with my healthcare team the effects of smoking, alcohol and drugs on my health condition/disability.
I have discussed with my healthcare team how my health condition/disability may impact on my sexual and reproductive health.
I know my medication/s, and treatment routine.
I know which tests/investigations I have regularly and why I need them.
I know the side effects and restrictions of my medications/s.
I am responsible for remembering and administrating my medication or treatment.
I am responsible for getting a repeat of my prescription and having it filled.
I know what equipment I need and what it is used for.
I know how to organise/reorder any equipment I may require.
I know who to contact for medical advice, including medical emergencies or outside hours.
I can make my own appointments within the health services I currently use.
I know how to reschedule or change my appointments if necessary.
I know I can have/I have had time with my doctor or healthcare staff in my appointment by myself.
I feel comfortable asking my doctor to further explain information that is not clear to me.
I know how to organise payment of my contribution.
I have received oral and written information about my rights as a healthcare user.
I know what my right to informed consent means.
I know what confidentiality means.
I have a regular GP I trust and feel comfortable talking to.
I know where to get advice about m health issues.
I know what to do if I become unwell or need urgent medical assistance.
I know who to contact if I need urgent medical support after hours.
I recognise the importance of a balanced lifestyle (nutrition, fitness, recreation, leisure and education).
I know whether my condition sets limitations for my vocational choices.
I know how/where to get educational/vocational support.
I know how/where to get support with my work commitments.
I feel confident advocating for myself.
I have strategies/supports in place if I am feeling stressed or upset-
I know patient organisations for my health issue and if there is a youth group I can join.
I know how to get information/support about sexual health and relationship issues.
I know how to get support about my mental health.
I have information about the differences between adult services and paediatric services.
I have developed a transition plan with a member of my healthcare team.
I have a copy of my medical summary from the hospital-
I feel prepared to transfer to an adult service.
I have the contact details of the new health service.
I have toured the new heath service and know how to get there-
I have met few members of the healthcare staff I will be seeing at the adult service.
I know how to book and change appointments at my new health service.
I have written my own referral letter to my new doctor.
I have an appointment booked for my new health service.
